entity.name: Mixins
entity.description: Group and reuse definitions dynamically.
entity.descriptionClean: Group and reuse definitions dynamically.

entity.name: Masonry Layout
entity.description: Native support for Pinterest-style free-flowing grid layouts.
entity.descriptionClean: Native support for Pinterest-style free-flowing grid layouts.

webFeature.description_html: Masonry is a type of CSS grid layout where the items on one of the axes are tightly packed together, like brickwork, instead of leaving gaps to align across the other axis.
webFeature.name: Masonry

example.codeHighlighted: .parent { color: blue; .child { color: red; } }

webFeature.description_html: CSS nesting allows for shorter selectors, easier reading, and more modularity by nesting rules inside others.
webFeature.name: Nesting

entity.name: Browser support
entity.description: Browser support, compatibility, and consistency issues.
entity.descriptionClean: Browser support, compatibility, and consistency issues.

webFeature.description_html: The column-fill CSS property sets the distribution of content across columns in a multi-column layout.
webFeature.name: column-fill

example.codeHighlighted: a:has(> img) { border: 2px solid grey; }

webFeature.description_html: The :has() CSS functional pseudo-class matches an element if any of the selectors passed as parameters would match at least one element.
webFeature.name: :has()

webFeature.description_html: The position: sticky CSS declaration positions an element in the normal flow until it crosses a specified threshold, at which points it becomes fixed (stuck) at that position.
webFeature.name: Sticky positioning

example.codeHighlighted: .anchor { anchor-name: --my-anchor; } .target { position: absolute; position-anchor: --my-anchor; position-area: start end; }

resources.title: Tether elements to each other with CSS anchor positioning

webFeature.description_html: Anchor positioning places an element based on the position of another element. For example, you can place a tooltip next to the content it references.
webFeature.name: Anchor positioning

entity.name: `:stuck`
entity.description: A selector for targeting “stuck” `position: sticky` items
entity.descriptionHtml: A selector for targeting “stuck” position: sticky items
entity.descriptionClean: A selector for targeting “stuck” position: sticky items

example.codeHighlighted: p { text-box-edge: cap alphabetic; text-box-trim: trim-both; }

resources.title: Leading-Trim: The Future of Digital Typesetting

example.codeHighlighted: @container (min-width: 700px) { .card { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 2fr 1fr; } }

webFeature.description_html: Container size queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the dimensions of its container.
webFeature.name: Container queries

example.codeHighlighted: p { display: -webkit-box; -webkit-line-clamp: 2; -webkit-box-orient: vertical; overflow: hidden; }

webFeature.description_html: The line-clamp CSS property limits the text in a block container to a certain number of lines. The prefixed -webkit-line-clamp is widely supported but only works with -webkit-box-orient: vertical in combination with display: -webkit-box or display: -webkit-inline-box.
webFeature.name: line-clamp

entity.name: Improved `attr()`
entity.description: Support for properties other than content
entity.descriptionClean: Support for properties other than content

entity.name: Customizable Select
entity.description: Stylable, customizable dropdown control. Previously `<selectlist>` and `<selectmenu>`.
entity.descriptionHtml: Stylable, customizable dropdown control. Previously <selectlist> and <selectmenu>.
entity.descriptionClean: Stylable, customizable dropdown control. Previously <selectlist> and <selectmenu>.

example.codeHighlighted: select, ::picker(select) { appearance: base-select; }

resources.title: The selectmenu HTML Tag | CSS-Tricks - CSS-Tricks
Advanced Form Control Styling With Selectmenu And Anchoring API — Smashing Magazine

webFeature.description_html: The <select> element's appearance, including the button, selected option, picker dropdown, and options, can be customized using CSS.
webFeature.name: Customizable <select>

resources.title: Smooth and simple transitions with the View Transitions API

webFeature.description_html: The @view-transition CSS rule sets whether a document opts-in to transitions between documents in a multi-page application. Both the old and new document must opt-in for a transition to be triggered.
webFeature.name: Cross-document view transitions

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { color-scheme: light dark; }

webFeature.description_html: The color-scheme CSS property sets which color schemes (light or dark) an element uses and may prevent automatic dark mode adjustments by the browser.
webFeature.name: color-scheme

example.codeHighlighted: .box { backdrop-filter: blur(10px); }

webFeature.description_html: The backdrop-filter CSS property applies graphical effects such as blurring or color shifting to the area behind an element.
webFeature.name: backdrop-filter

entity.name: `<input type="color">`
entity.description: Creates a color picker from which users can choose a color value.
entity.descriptionClean: Creates a color picker from which users can choose a color value.

webFeature.description_html: The <input type="color"> HTML element shows a color picker from which users can choose a color value.
webFeature.name: <input type="color">

example.codeHighlighted: .contain { object-fit: contain; }
@layer layer-name {rules}

webFeature.description_html: The @layer CSS at-rule avoids specificity conflicts by providing priority levels for different groups of CSS rules, such as low-priority styles like resets, and high-priority styles like UI components.
webFeature.name: Cascade layers

entity.name: File System Access API
entity.description: Access files and directories on the user's local device and create writable files that can be updated.
entity.descriptionHtml: Access files and directories on the user's local device and create writable files that can be updated.
entity.descriptionClean: Access files and directories on the user's local device and create writable files that can be updated.

example.codeHighlighted: const handle = await window.showSaveFilePicker(); const writable = await handle.createWritable(); await writable.write("Hello, world!"); await writable.close();

webFeature.description_html: The showOpenFilePicker(), showDirectoryPicker(), and showSaveFilePicker() methods request access to files and directories on the user's device and returns a handle for reading and writing to them.
webFeature.name: File system access

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()

entity.name: Media Queries Variables
entity.description: Being able to use variables inside media queries.
entity.descriptionClean: Being able to use variables inside media queries.

example.codeHighlighted: :where(header, main, footer) p:hover { color: red; cursor: pointer; }

webFeature.description_html: The :where() CSS functional pseudo-class takes a selector list as its argument, and matches any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. It is functionally equivalent to the selectors in the list, but doesn't affect the CSS rule specificity.
webFeature.name: :where()

example.codeHighlighted: .high-contrast { color: color-contrast(#008080 vs olive, var(--myColor), #d2691e); }
li::marker { content: '⭐️ '; }
.brightest-green { background: color(display-p3 0 1 0); }

webFeature.description_html: The color() function picks a color from a given color space. Wide gamut color spaces like display-p3 allow showing more vibrant and saturated colors than the standard srgb color space.
webFeature.name: color()

resources.title: Can we have custom media queries, please?

example.codeHighlighted: @container (min-width: 700px) { .card { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 2fr 1fr; } }

webFeature.description_html: Container size queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the dimensions of its container.
webFeature.name: Container queries

example.codeHighlighted: .element { height: 0; overflow: hidden; transition: height 0.3s; } .element.open { height: calc-size(auto); }

resources.title: CSS interpolate-size property and calc-size() function

webFeature.description_html: The calc-size() CSS function computes mathematical expressions that include height and width keyword values, for example calc-size(fit-content, size / 2). Not to be confused with the calc() CSS function, which cannot use keyword values.
webFeature.name: calc-size()

example.codeHighlighted: .square { aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; }

webFeature.description_html: The aspect-ratio CSS property controls the width-to-height ratio of elements. For <img> and <video> elements, the width and height attributes used together with height: auto control the aspect ratio while the image/video is loading.
webFeature.name: aspect-ratio

entity.name: Shapes
entity.description: `shape-image-threshold`, `shape-margin`, `shape-outside`
entity.descriptionClean: shape-image-threshold, shape-margin, shape-outside

example.codeHighlighted: img { float: left; shape-outside: circle(50%); }

entity.name: `@import`
entity.description: The @import CSS at-rule is used to import style rules from other valid stylesheets.
entity.descriptionClean: The @import CSS at-rule is used to import style rules from other valid stylesheets.

example.codeHighlighted: @import url("my-imported-styles.css");
.wrap { text-wrap: wrap; }

entity.name: Grid-lines Styling
entity.description: The ability to style the invisible lines that divide a grid.
entity.descriptionClean: The ability to style the invisible lines that divide a grid.

entity.name: `<details>` and `<summary>`
entity.description: A disclosure widget that can be toggled to hide or show content interactively.
entity.descriptionClean: A disclosure widget that can be toggled to hide or show content interactively.

example.codeHighlighted: <details> <summary>Details</summary> Longer content </details>

webFeature.description_html: The <details> element is a disclosure widget which can be expanded to reveal additional content. When closed, only the nested <summary> element is visible.
webFeature.name: <details>

example.codeHighlighted: #container { height: 300px; overflow-y: scroll; scroll-timeline: --squareTimeline y; position: relative; }

webFeature.description_html: The animation-timeline, scroll-timeline, and view-timeline CSS properties advance animations based on the user's scroll position.
webFeature.name: Scroll-driven animations

entity.name: Discrete Properties Animations
entity.description: Animate to and from properties such as `display: none`
entity.descriptionHtml: Animate to and from properties such as display: none
entity.descriptionClean: Animate to and from properties such as display: none

example.codeHighlighted: /* IS-OPEN STATE */ dialog[open] { translate: 0 0; } /* EXIT STATE */ dialog { transition: opacity 1s, display 1s allow-discrete, overlay 1s allow-discrete; translate: 0 100vh; } /* 0. BEFORE-OPEN STATE */ @starting-style { dialog[open] { translate: 0 100vh; } }

webFeature.description_html: The transition-behavior: allow-discrete CSS declaration allows transitions for properties whose animation behavior is discrete. Such properties can't be interpolated and swap from their start value to the end value at 50%.
webFeature.name: transition-behavior

example.codeHighlighted: .focus-visible-only:focus-visible { outline: 2px dashed darkorange; }

webFeature.description_html: The :focus-visible CSS pseudo-class selects elements that match the :focus pseudo-class and meets the browser's criteria for visually emphasizing focused elements.
webFeature.name: :focus-visible

entity.name: Focus management
entity.description: Managing user focus
entity.descriptionClean: Managing user focus

entity.name: `animation-timeline`
entity.description: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.
entity.descriptionClean: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.

example.codeHighlighted: #square { animation-name: rotateAnimation; animation-direction: alternate; animation-timeline: --squareTimeline; }

entity.name: Intrinsic Sizing
entity.description: `min-content`, `max-content`, `fit-content`
entity.descriptionClean: min-content, max-content, fit-content

example.codeHighlighted: h2 { width: max-content; }

webFeature.description_html: The min-content and max-content CSS keywords represent the smallest and largest intrinsic sizes of an element.
webFeature.name: min-content and max-content

example.codeHighlighted: .box { background-image: image-set( url("small-balloons.jpg") 1x, url("large-balloons.jpg") 2x); }

webFeature.description_html: The image-set() CSS function provides a set of images at different resolutions or pixel densities, which the browser can pick from, depending on the device capabilities.
webFeature.name: image-set()

entity.name: `<dialog>`
entity.description: Creates a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.
entity.descriptionClean: Creates a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.

example.code:
<dialog id="confirm">
	<form method="dialog">
		Are you sure?
		<button value="1">Yes</button>
		<button value="0">No</button>
	</form>
</dialog>
example.codeHighlighted: <dialog id="confirm"> <form method="dialog"> Are you sure? <button value="1">Yes</button> <button value="0">No</button> </form> </dialog>

webFeature.description_html: The <dialog> HTML element represents a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.
webFeature.name: <dialog>

example.codeHighlighted: .teal { background: color-mix(in lab, white 20%, #34c9eb); }

webFeature.description_html: The color-mix() function mixes two colors in a given color space and by a given amount. Commonly, lighter or darker variations of a color are created by mixing with white or black.
webFeature.name: color-mix()

example.codeHighlighted: .vertical-text { writing-mode: vertical-lr; }

webFeature.description_html: The writing-mode CSS property sets whether text is laid out horizontally or vertically, and left to right, or right to left.
webFeature.name: writing-mode

example.codeHighlighted: .wrapper { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; } .item { grid-row: 1 / 4; display: grid; grid-template-rows: subgrid; }

webFeature.description_html: The subgrid value for the grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows properties allows a grid item to inherit the grid definition of its parent grid container.
webFeature.name: Subgrid

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { --color: #4488dd; background-color: hsl(from var(--color) h s calc(l * 1.2)) }

resources.title: Create a color theme with CSS Relative Color Syntax, CSS color-mix(), and CSS color-contrast()

webFeature.description_html: The from keyword for color functions (color(), hsl(), oklch(), etc.) creates a new color based on a given color by modifying the values of the input color. Also known as relative color syntax (RCS).
webFeature.name: Relative colors

example.codeHighlighted: @container style(--fontColor: green) { /* <stylesheet> */ }

webFeature.description_html: Container style queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the values of custom properties of its container.
webFeature.name: Container style queries

example.codeHighlighted: section { display: flex gap: 1em 2em; }
@property --property-name { syntax: "<color>"; inherits: false; initial-value: #c0ffee; }

webFeature.description_html: The CSS.registerProperty() static method and the @property CSS at-rule register custom properties for which types and behaviors can be defined.
webFeature.name: Registered custom properties

entity.description: `::part()`, `:host()`, `::slotted()`
entity.descriptionClean: ::part(), :host(), ::slotted()

entity.name: Visually Hidden Content
entity.description: Native support for visually hidden content.
entity.descriptionClean: Native support for visually hidden content.

example.codeHighlighted: @supports (display: table-cell) and (display: list-item) { //... }

webFeature.description_html: The @supports at-rule applies styles based on a browser's support for CSS features, such as a CSS property and value. Also known as feature queries.
webFeature.name: @supports

entity.name: More Pseudo-Elements
entity.description: Having more than two pseudo-elements per element.
entity.descriptionClean: Having more than two pseudo-elements per element.

example.codeHighlighted: .balanced { max-inline-size: 50ch; text-wrap: balance; }

webFeature.description_html: The text-wrap: balance CSS declaration balances the length of each line when text is broken into multiple lines. Also known as headline balancing.
webFeature.name: text-wrap: balance

entity.name: Dynamic Text Color
entity.description: Change text color based on background
entity.descriptionClean: Change text color based on background

entity.name: `inert` attribute
entity.description: Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology.
entity.descriptionClean: Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology.

example.codeHighlighted: <div id=app inert class=loading> ... </div>

resources.title: The "inert" attribute is finally coming to the web | Stefan Judis Web Development

webFeature.description_html: The inert HTML attribute marks an element and its descendants as non-interactive. Inert elements don't get focus or fire click events.
webFeature.name: inert

entity.name: Autocomplete
entity.description: Autocomplete, comboxbox, typeahead, etc. inputs
entity.descriptionClean: Autocomplete, comboxbox, typeahead, etc. inputs

entity.name: Declarative Shadow DOM
entity.description: Define shadow trees with HTML, such as when server-side-rendering web components.
entity.descriptionClean: Define shadow trees with HTML, such as when server-side-rendering web components.

example.codeHighlighted: <host-element> <template shadowrootmode="open"> <!-- Shadow content --> </template> </host-element>

resources.title: GitHub - mfreed7/declarative-shadow-dom: Declarative Shadow DOM feature development

webFeature.description_html: The shadowrootmode attribute on <template> creates a shadow root without the use of JavaScript. It is a declarative alternative to the attachShadow() method.
webFeature.name: Declarative shadow DOM

entity.name: HTML imports
entity.description: Lack of native HTML imports or templating
entity.descriptionClean: Lack of native HTML imports or templating

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()

entity.name: Shadow DOM
entity.description: Encapsulate elements not visible from the outside, and style them with CSS not affecting the rest of the page.
entity.descriptionClean: Encapsulate elements not visible from the outside, and style them with CSS not affecting the rest of the page.

example.codeHighlighted: this.shadowRoot = this.attachShadow({mode: "open"});

webFeature.description_html: Shadow DOM allows you to attach encapsulated "shadow" DOM trees to elements. A shadow DOM tree is a separate component, isolated from the scripts and styles in other parts of the document. This is a part of Web Components.
webFeature.name: Shadow DOM

entity.name: `<details name>` (Exclusive Accordion)
entity.description: Group `<details>` elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.
entity.descriptionHtml: Group <details> elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.
entity.descriptionClean: Group <details> elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.

example.code:
<details open name="sidebar_panel">
	<summary>Main info</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
<details name="sidebar_panel">
	<summary>Style</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
example.codeHighlighted: <details open name="sidebar_panel"> <summary>Main info</summary> <!-- controls --> </details> <details name="sidebar_panel"> <summary>Style</summary> <!-- controls --> </details>

resources.title: Add name attribute for grouping details elements into an exclusive accordion by dbaron · Pull Request #9400 · whatwg/html · GitHub
Exclusive accordion (<details name="">) · Issue #866 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub

webFeature.description_html: Multiple <details> elements which use the same name attribute are mutually exclusive. When one member of the group is opened, all other members are closed.
webFeature.name: Mutually exclusive <details> elements

entity.name: JPEG XL
entity.description: An image format optimized for web environments.
entity.descriptionClean: An image format optimized for web environments.

example.codeHighlighted: <img src="image.jxl" />
@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) { .foo { background: #333; color: white; } }

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-color-scheme CSS media query sets styles based on the requested color scheme, light or dark.
webFeature.name: prefers-color-scheme media query

example.codeHighlighted: code { color: light-dark(black, white); }

webFeature.description_html: The light-dark() CSS function accepts two colors and uses one depending on the current color scheme.
webFeature.name: light-dark()

entity.description: `mix-blend-mode`, `background-blend-mode`, `isolation`
entity.descriptionClean: mix-blend-mode, background-blend-mode, isolation

example.codeHighlighted: .item2 { color: #000; mix-blend-mode: overlay; }

webFeature.description_html: The mix-blend-mode CSS property blends an element's content with its background or parent elements using blend modes like multiply, difference, or color.
webFeature.name: mix-blend-mode

example.codeHighlighted: @font-face { font-family: "Fraunces"; src: url("fraunces.woff2") format("woff2"); font-weight: 200 700; } h2 { font-family: "Fraunces"; font-variation-settings: "wght" 375, "SOFT" 100; }

webFeature.description_html: The font-variation-settings CSS property sets an "axis of variability" on a variable font, such as weight, optical size, or a custom axis defined by the typeface designer. When possible, use other CSS font properties, such as font-weight: bold. Also known as variable fonts.
webFeature.name: font-variation-settings

entity.name: Scroll Snap
entity.description: `scroll-snap-type`, `scroll-snap-align`, `scroll-padding`…
entity.descriptionClean: scroll-snap-type, scroll-snap-align, scroll-padding…

example.codeHighlighted: .scroller { height: 300px; overflow-y: scroll; scroll-snap-type: y mandatory; } .scroller section { scroll-snap-align: start; }

webFeature.description_html: CSS scroll snap controls the panning and scrolling behavior within a scroll container.
webFeature.name: Scroll snap

example.codeHighlighted: input[type='checkbox'] { accent-color: tomato; }

webFeature.description_html: The accent-color CSS property sets a color for checkboxes, radio buttons, and other form controls.
webFeature.name: accent-color

entity.name: CSS Logical Properties
entity.description: `margin-block-start`, `padding-inline-end`, `border-inline-start`…
entity.descriptionClean: margin-block-start, padding-inline-end, border-inline-start…

example.codeHighlighted: section { border-block: 8px solid blue; border-inline: 8px solid green; }

webFeature.description_html: CSS logical properties control borders, size, margin, and padding with directions and dimensions relative to the writing mode. For example, in a left to right, top to bottom writing mode, block-end refers to the bottom. Also known as flow relative.
webFeature.name: Logical properties

example.codeHighlighted: .image{ filter: blur(5px) }
.blue-text { color: blue; } .blue-text .blue-background { background: currentColor; }

entity.name: `<datalist>`
entity.description: Method of providing a list of presets for a user to select in a form control, while still allowing custom options.
entity.descriptionClean: Method of providing a list of presets for a user to select in a form control, while still allowing custom options.

example.codeHighlighted: <input name="country" list="countries"> <datalist id="countries"> <option>Afghanistan</option> ... </datalist>

webFeature.description_html: The <datalist> element sets recommended values for an <input> element. Browsers may show a dropdown menu of all values or match values as the user types.
webFeature.name: <datalist>

entity.name: `popover="hint"`
entity.description: A way to create less persistent popovers, such as tooltips.
entity.descriptionClean: A way to create less persistent popovers, such as tooltips.

example.code: Save this document
example.codeHighlighted: <div id="tooltip" popover="hint"> Save this document </div> <button popovertarget="tooltip"> Save </button>

webFeature.description_html: The popover="hint" global HTML attribute creates a popover that is subordinate to popovers with a popover="auto" attribute. You can use this to create tooltips that don't dismiss auto popovers.
webFeature.name: popover="hint"

entity.name: `:has-slotted`
entity.description: CSS pseudo-class that allows targeting `<slot>` elements only when they have slotted nodes.
entity.descriptionHtml: CSS pseudo-class that allows targeting <slot> elements only when they have slotted nodes.
entity.descriptionClean: CSS pseudo-class that allows targeting <slot> elements only when they have slotted nodes.

webFeature.description_html: The :has-slotted CSS pseudo-class matches <slot> elements where the fallback content is not shown. The pseudo-class matches any slotted content, including white space, text nodes, or elements.
webFeature.name: :has-slotted

example.codeHighlighted: .blue-text { color: blue; } .blue-text .blue-background { background: currentColor; }

entity.name: `<dialog>`
entity.description: Creates a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.
entity.descriptionClean: Creates a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.

example.code:
<dialog id="confirm">
	<form method="dialog">
		Are you sure?
		<button value="1">Yes</button>
		<button value="0">No</button>
	</form>
</dialog>
example.codeHighlighted: <dialog id="confirm"> <form method="dialog"> Are you sure? <button value="1">Yes</button> <button value="0">No</button> </form> </dialog>

webFeature.description_html: The <dialog> HTML element represents a modal or non-modal dialog box, such as a confirmation prompt or a subwindow used to enter data.
webFeature.name: <dialog>

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { color-scheme: light dark; }

webFeature.description_html: The color-scheme CSS property sets which color schemes (light or dark) an element uses and may prevent automatic dark mode adjustments by the browser.
webFeature.name: color-scheme

example.codeHighlighted: code { color: light-dark(black, white); }

webFeature.description_html: The light-dark() CSS function accepts two colors and uses one depending on the current color scheme.
webFeature.name: light-dark()

entity.name: `inert` attribute
entity.description: Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology.
entity.descriptionClean: Attribute to make an element and its descendants non-interactive, and invisible to assistive technology.

example.codeHighlighted: <div id=app inert class=loading> ... </div>

resources.title: The "inert" attribute is finally coming to the web | Stefan Judis Web Development

webFeature.description_html: The inert HTML attribute marks an element and its descendants as non-interactive. Inert elements don't get focus or fire click events.
webFeature.name: inert

example.codeHighlighted: .image{ filter: blur(5px) }

entity.name: Shapes
entity.description: `shape-image-threshold`, `shape-margin`, `shape-outside`
entity.descriptionClean: shape-image-threshold, shape-margin, shape-outside

example.codeHighlighted: img { float: left; shape-outside: circle(50%); }
button { --background-color: darkblue; background-color: var(--background-color); color: contrast-color(var(--background-color)); }

webFeature.description_html: The contrast-color() CSS function picks a color that has guaranteed contrast against a specified foreground or background color.
webFeature.name: contrast-color()

example.codeHighlighted: :where(header, main, footer) p:hover { color: red; cursor: pointer; }

webFeature.description_html: The :where() CSS functional pseudo-class takes a selector list as its argument, and matches any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. It is functionally equivalent to the selectors in the list, but doesn't affect the CSS rule specificity.
webFeature.name: :where()

entity.name: `loading="lazy"`
entity.description: Load certain resources only when needed.
entity.descriptionClean: Load certain resources only when needed.

example.codeHighlighted: <img src="picture.jpg" loading="lazy" /> <iframe src="supplementary.html" loading="lazy"></iframe>

resources.title: Browser-level image lazy loading for the web

webFeature.description_html: The loading="lazy" attribute for <img> and <iframe> elements blocks loading the external resource until the user scrolls to that element's part of the page.
webFeature.name: Lazy-loading images and iframes

example.codeHighlighted: .teal { background: color-mix(in lab, white 20%, #34c9eb); }

webFeature.description_html: The color-mix() function mixes two colors in a given color space and by a given amount. Commonly, lighter or darker variations of a color are created by mixing with white or black.
webFeature.name: color-mix()

example.codeHighlighted: .wrap { text-wrap: wrap; }

entity.name: More Pseudo-Elements
entity.description: Having more than two pseudo-elements per element.
entity.descriptionClean: Having more than two pseudo-elements per element.

example.codeHighlighted: :root { --main-bg-color: brown; } .foo { background-color: var(--main-bg-color); }

entity.name: Discrete Properties Animations
entity.description: Animate to and from properties such as `display: none`
entity.descriptionHtml: Animate to and from properties such as display: none
entity.descriptionClean: Animate to and from properties such as display: none

example.codeHighlighted: /* IS-OPEN STATE */ dialog[open] { translate: 0 0; } /* EXIT STATE */ dialog { transition: opacity 1s, display 1s allow-discrete, overlay 1s allow-discrete; translate: 0 100vh; } /* 0. BEFORE-OPEN STATE */ @starting-style { dialog[open] { translate: 0 100vh; } }

webFeature.description_html: The transition-behavior: allow-discrete CSS declaration allows transitions for properties whose animation behavior is discrete. Such properties can't be interpolated and swap from their start value to the end value at 50%.
webFeature.name: transition-behavior

example.codeHighlighted: @media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) { .animation { animation: none; } }

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-reduced-motion CSS media query sets styles based on whether the user prefers to minimize the amount of non-essential animations on the device, such as scrolling, panning, zooming, and strobing.
webFeature.name: prefers-reduced-motion media query

entity.name: Declarative Shadow DOM
entity.description: Define shadow trees with HTML, such as when server-side-rendering web components.
entity.descriptionClean: Define shadow trees with HTML, such as when server-side-rendering web components.

example.codeHighlighted: <host-element> <template shadowrootmode="open"> <!-- Shadow content --> </template> </host-element>

resources.title: GitHub - mfreed7/declarative-shadow-dom: Declarative Shadow DOM feature development

webFeature.description_html: The shadowrootmode attribute on <template> creates a shadow root without the use of JavaScript. It is a declarative alternative to the attachShadow() method.
webFeature.name: Declarative shadow DOM

entity.name: HTML imports
entity.description: Lack of native HTML imports or templating
entity.descriptionClean: Lack of native HTML imports or templating

example.codeHighlighted: a:has(> img) { border: 2px solid grey; }

webFeature.description_html: The :has() CSS functional pseudo-class matches an element if any of the selectors passed as parameters would match at least one element.
webFeature.name: :has()

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()

example.codeHighlighted: .element { height: 0; overflow: hidden; transition: height 0.3s; } .element.open { height: calc-size(auto); }

resources.title: CSS interpolate-size property and calc-size() function

webFeature.description_html: The calc-size() CSS function computes mathematical expressions that include height and width keyword values, for example calc-size(fit-content, size / 2). Not to be confused with the calc() CSS function, which cannot use keyword values.
webFeature.name: calc-size()

entity.name: `animation-timeline`
entity.description: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.
entity.descriptionClean: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.

example.codeHighlighted: #square { animation-name: rotateAnimation; animation-direction: alternate; animation-timeline: --squareTimeline; }
@container (min-width: 700px) { .card { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 2fr 1fr; } }

webFeature.description_html: Container size queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the dimensions of its container.
webFeature.name: Container queries

webFeature.description_html: The column-fill CSS property sets the distribution of content across columns in a multi-column layout.
webFeature.name: column-fill

entity.name: Dynamic Text Color
entity.description: Change text color based on background
entity.descriptionClean: Change text color based on background

entity.name: Advanced `attr()`
entity.description: Support for properties other than content
entity.descriptionClean: Support for properties other than content

example.codeHighlighted: .title { background-color: attr(data-color type(<color>)); }

resources.title: First Look at The Modern attr()

webFeature.description_html: The attr() CSS function, in the context of any property, returns the value of an attribute of an HTML element, with the option to return it as a specific type or unit. You can set a default value for missing or invalid attributes.
webFeature.name: attr()

entity.name: Visually Hidden Content
entity.description: Native support for visually hidden content.
entity.descriptionClean: Native support for visually hidden content.

entity.name: Autocomplete
entity.description: Autocomplete, comboxbox, typeahead, etc. inputs
entity.descriptionClean: Autocomplete, comboxbox, typeahead, etc. inputs

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()

entity.name: ARIA
entity.description: `role` and `aria-*` attributes
entity.descriptionClean: role and aria-* attributes

example.code: Prices
example.codeHighlighted: <div id="tab1" aria-controls="panel1" role="tab">Prices</div> <div id="panel1" class="panel" aria-labelledby="tab1" role="tabpanel"> <!-- tab content --> </div>

entity.name: Comparison Functions
entity.description: `min()`, `max()`, `clamp()`
entity.descriptionClean: min(), max(), clamp()

example.codeHighlighted: .element { width: clamp(100px, 50vw, 600px); }

webFeature.description_html: The min() and max() CSS functions return the minimum or maximum of the arguments, while clamp() clamps a value to a given range.
webFeature.name: min(), max(), and clamp()

example.codeHighlighted: .brightest-green { background: color(display-p3 0 1 0); }

webFeature.description_html: The color() function picks a color from a given color space. Wide gamut color spaces like display-p3 allow showing more vibrant and saturated colors than the standard srgb color space.
webFeature.name: color()

example.codeHighlighted: .high-contrast { color: color-contrast(#008080 vs olive, var(--myColor), #d2691e); }

entity.name: `popover` attribute (Popover API)
entity.description: HTML syntax and JS API facilitating popovers such as overlays, popups, menus etc.
entity.descriptionClean: HTML syntax and JS API facilitating popovers such as overlays, popups, menus etc.

example.code: Popover content
example.codeHighlighted: <button popovertarget="foo">Toggle the popover</button> <div id="foo" popover>Popover content</div>

resources.title: The Popover API (previously Popup) · Issue #743 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub

webFeature.description_html: The popover HTML attribute creates an overlay to display content on top of other page content. Popovers can be shown declaratively using HTML, or using the showPopover() method.
webFeature.name: Popover

example.codeHighlighted: .carousel { &::scroll-button(left) { content: "⬅" / "Scroll Left"; } &::scroll-button(right) { content: "⮕" / "Scroll Right"; } &::scroll-button(*):focus-visible { outline-offset: 5px; } }

webFeature.description_html: A scroll container can be navigated by activating ::scroll-marker pseudo-elements which appear in a generated ::scroll-marker-group pseudo-element, either before or after the scroll container.
webFeature.name: Scroll markers
